review_title: Abington Memorial Hospital has been a home to me for many years and I am so grateful for what I have learned.
pros:
Most departments are friendly and easy to work with except ETC they seem to have their own clique. 
Flexible with picking up hours I wanted.
Large organizations many different fields to work in. 
The staff overall is friendly.
cons:
Often not enough staff on floors that are heavy which could lead to patient safety issues 
Initial training for new staff members is weak and disjointed, many of the skills I learned were from hands on experience that I had to learn for myself and months later I would receive training for skills. 
"Internal Hiring" - They say the hire internally but you really have to fight to get an interview regardless.
HR department is horrible. I had a simple question only one of the business partners in HR could answer I left 4 messages over 2 months and stopped by the office twice and still couldn't get a hold of her until I went over her head.

review_title: Good place to start, not much room for growth
pros: Benefits, travel distance (for me, at least,) friendly coworkers, paid time off, pay (at least to start,) general environment.  A good first  job.  Middle management seems to have genuine concern for their subordinates.  It is a great place to work if you just want to sit back and coast and collect a paycheck.
cons: Very difficult to get promoted.  Who you know is much more important than what your abilities and accomplishments are.  Senior management seems more concerned about doing things that will earn them bonuses than preserving the jobs of their subordinates.  No financial rewards for exceptional perfmance--management believes in giving across the board raises (when they have the money to do so--not this year,) even to the incompetent, rather than rewarding those who do a really good job.

pros: Great colleagues to work with; good teamwork amongst nursing staff; fun environment; tuition reimbursement; retirement plan offered; paid CPR, PALS, and ACLS classes.
cons: High patient to nurse ratios; inadequate number of ancillary staff; outdated or broken equipment; often run out of needed supplies; charting very lengthy; nurse assignment often seems overwhelming with many high acuity patients; forced on-call time in some departments; must work every-other holiday; poor pay compared to city hospitals.

pros: The people!  I worked with all the attending medical staff and their office support staff.  My job was to be a liaison between the on and off campus medical practice with the various ancillary services within the main hospital(s) as well as administration and any/all updates as to the ongoing changes/enhancements that the hospitals were undergoing.
cons: Very few raises, and minimal at best.  There was more emphasis toward the medical practices that were owned by the hospital, predominantly primary care physicians and not enough toward the referring doctors and surgeons.

pros: Job security and autonomy plus the opportunity to expand my role outside of that of the traditional NP. I have the opportunity to do many different "jobs" in my current role keeping the day challenging and varied.
cons: Sometimes limited by bureaucratic rules. Its also difficult to figure out how to get involved in a 'topic' if it is something that you would like to help with. I believe its mostly time and figuring out who the correct person is to ask, but it can be difficult.

pros: My coworkers are very consistent in helping one another.
cons: It's hard to advance within the hospital system if you do not have a degree. And it appears management takes care of their friends and family before hiring within. Extremely unfair.

review_title: After working at this establishment for 15 years
pros: Ran a department of nine, had deadlines and the Job was a challenge which I enjoyed. I was able to advance over the years.
cons: Would have liked to see employees work better together. Needed to find a way to keep employees morale up. The Hospital at one point made their employees feel like they were very important and as time has come around now they make their employees feel like they are lucky to still be employed. It was very sad to watch especially with a heavier work load.

pros: If you have a good supervisor like I do, working here is tolerable.  My supervisor is very liberal with scheduling and . Will always help you out if an emergency arises.
cons: Healthcare benefits are getting lower and lower, upper management can be very deceiving, more Worried about the almighty dollar than patient care.

pros:
CLL was quite supportive when learning new skills and responded if available. Nursing educator
would also check on missing protocols for nursing procedures.
cons: Could not always get help when I asked my coworkers or CNA. I always took time to assist coworkers patients when I answered call lights. I felt overwhelmed and unable to get support when my patients were having critical issues. I did call the liaison,, but was told she was not available. Accused of not asking for help and assumed that I did not do enough for my patients.

job_title: Medical Office Receptionist in Warminster, PA
pros:
The office I worked in was one of the best I have ever worked in. I believe this was due to the physicians and the office manager. They always stressed family first and they actually meant it. They were understanding and flexible if you needed to switch your schedule with another staff member. The manager would give incentives for the staff to compliment each other to encourage teamwork. Everyone including the physicians were very down to earth and treated each other with respect. 
Even the new employee orientation was the best I've ever encountered. They were very thorough and kept it interesting with a variety of speakers,
cons: I can't think of any cons.

job_title: Nursing Care in South Abington Township, PA
pros: Very clean & professional on the surface, Good Drs, Impressive looking campus Good location. Some things are done very well. Parking is not a problem for most.
cons: Despite being Magnet certified, not all nurses agree. Some dissatisfied nurses are afraid to speak up - rightfully afraid to lose their jobs. Certain areas have very poor morale and it shows. Underpaid before Magnet, AMH makes an adjustment prior to Magnet survey.  Hospital appears too caught up in their community image and not on fundamentals that truly make or break their reputation - excellent nursing care. Happy nurses make happy patients.

review_title: Decent Job - Laid back for most part
pros: Pay, networking, work on your own. Made some great friends here and if you work as a transporter while in school, you an transfer departments when you finish.
cons: hours, holidays, weekends, coworkers. Lazy coworkers means constant call outs and less people on shift or in the worst case they show up and do no work. That means the rest of the hardworking employees must transport more patients than they normally would while the lazier employees sit and hide somewhere.

pros: Great co-workers and good support team among staff
cons: While upper management continues to receive bonuses they have RIF'd many employees.  Maybe they could have refused the bonuses and saved some nursing jobs.  Meanwhile staff is over worked and under paid and management doesn't care.  They pretend they do but they don't.  It's all about the numbers despite what they preach about Abington being a "family".  I guess the family only includes management.

pros: This is a great job to help people with an ever changing environment, and never have a slow or boring day.
cons: Work load can be too much (one person handling the job of at least 3 or 4 people), stalked by management if over on break or lunch, and supervisor makes job difficult with micromanagement of an already stressful job.

job_title: Data Integrity Audit Representative in Abington, PA
pros: They truly care about their employees and the patients well being. Patient Care is of the top priority. Supervisors are supportive. Atmosphere is delightful and only see positive interactions when walking the halls. Education is also important so they provide a generous education benefit to fulltime and halftime employees
cons: the only "con" I can really say is that the hiring process took extremely long... but no real "con's" to the working aspect

pros: A lot of my peers are also newer nurses - so not a lot of peer bullying . AMH hires RN without their BSN and offers compensation to further education
cons: Many of the support staff have an attitude when asked for help (kitchen staff, veni puncture).

review_title: not recommended for anyone or any reason.
pros:
not really any. 
employees are united against the overpaid suits running the place.
cons:
harsh place to work. you are not respected as a person. unrealistic expectations- 'reach for the stars' means you can't ever work hard enough for management. 
it is dangerously understaffed. and underpaid.

if you like doing the work of 2 or 3 people, getting no credit for it and getting totally humiliated at every performance review with getting publicly embarrassed on a regular basis, this place is for you.
its abusive on a daily basis

pros: The only pro is that I got acute hospital experience. That is is the only thing that I can think of.
cons: Very very racist staff. Most nurses do not hold a BSN, and they are the ones that try the most to assert their dominance and authority in almost everything that they do. As you can imagine, this creates a hostile and tense work environment. Nursing Manager has NO people skills at all. Poor example of a magnet hospital. Let's hope Jefferson gives the boot to all the under qualified, aggressive, racist nurses. The manager can go to!

pros: Coworkers are the best part of the position, the benefits offered, such as health, PTO, especially as a part-time employee are positive
cons: personal growth, compensation, managers do not value the evaluation process which leaves employees feeling under-valued

pros: Shared governance is promoted at Abington.  There are many opportunities for nurses to get involved in committees and voice their opinions to make positive changes in daily workflow.
cons: If you are a nurse with a specialty certification, it is a process to apply for the bonus.   You have to jump through so many hoops that it is not worth the extra effort in the end.

pros: Abington can feel like one big family.  The staff are all very friendly with one another and work together very well.
cons: Very busy hospital and pay scale should reflect this more.  Volumes are as high as city hospitals but do not pay as much.

pros: Good benefits-medical, dental, and vision, yearly 'cost of living raise', opportunity for advancement or to move to other departments, helpful colleagues,
cons: high stress for not enough pay, difficult to get needed time off, people in department are 'clique-y' making it uncomfortable to work at times, recommend the company, just not the department.

pros: The pay is good for my position but the work load makes patient care difficult.
cons: Not enough staff to handle the patient load, especially since Abington bought two local hospitals and their patients are now coming to Abington.

review_title: Coworkers are great.  Institution has a way to go to be innovative.
